review.title: Seeing Unseeability to See the Unseeable
review.abstract: We present a framework that allows an observer to determine occluded portions of a structure by finding the maximum-likelihood estimate of those occluded portions consistent with visible image evidence and a consistency model. Doing this requires determining which portions of the structure are occluded in the first place. Since each process relies on the other, we determine a solution to both problems in tandem. We extend our framework to determine confidence of one's assessment of which portions of an observed structure are occluded, and the estimate of that occluded structure, by determining the sensitivity of one's assessment to potential new observations. We further extend our framework to determine a robotic action whose execution would allow a new observation that would maximally increase one's confidence.

metadata.title: Seeing Unseeability to See the Unseeable

sections.text: We present a framework that allows an observer to determine closed parts of a structure by finding the most likely estimate of these locked parts, consistent with visible image evidence and a consistency model. To do this, we need to determine which parts of the structure are closed at all. Since each process is based on the other, we determine a solution to both problems in tandem. We expand our framework to determine the reliability of our own assessment of which parts of an observed structure are closed, and the estimation of that locked structure by determining the sensitivity of our own assessment to potential new observations. We expand our framework further to determine a robot-assisted action that would allow new observation to be performed that would maximize one's confidence.

sections.heading: 5 Gathering Additional Evidence to Improve Structure Estimation
sections.text: We must ask ourselves whether it is at all possible that the structures of the montage, which could otherwise be viewed from different angles, can be used in a structure other than the structure of the montage, which would otherwise be captured by higher layers. Generally, we are looking for a method to derive a single estimate of an initial structure with multiple log functions from different angles and different stages of disassembly.We can further combine this method. sections.heading: 6 Natural language
sections.text: An interesting feature of our framework is that it allows the elegant inclusion of information from other modalities that are considered as such. Natural language, for example, can be integrated into our approach to extract additional evidence for estimating the structure from statements describing the structure in question. A sentence or sentence describing a structure does not need to clearly specify the structure. Similar to additional images from novel angles, supplementary but partial evidence for estimating the structure can be provided, sentences that provide incomplete descriptions of structural features can also provide complementary but partial evidence for estimating the structure. We have explored this possibility by using a small domain-specific language to describe some common features present in assembly toys. This language has: two nouns (windows and door), four spatial relationships (left of, right of, perpendicular to, and coplanar to), and a conjunction (and). Sentences constructed from these words can easily be placed in a series of Asian analogies, such as a valid assembly.

sections.heading: 8 Related work
sections.text: Our work shares three general objectives with previous work: estimating the 3D structure from 2D images, determining when there are closures, and active vision. However, our work examines each of these problems from a novel perspective. In contrast, our work focuses on restoring the constituent structure of an assembly: which parts are used to make the assembly and how such parts are combined. Existing state-of-the-art surface reconstruction methods (e.g. Make3D et al., 2008) are unable to determine the surface structure of an assembly, and how these parts are combined.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: We have a general framework for (a) seeing the unpredictable, (b) seeing the unpredictable, (c) seeing the unpredictable, (c) a rational basis for determining confidence in what one sees, and (d) a decision-making process of active vision to determine rational behavior in the presence of unpredictability. We have initiated and evaluated our general framework in the LINCOLN LOG domain and found that it is effective. This framework has many potential extensions. You can construct random variables to represent uncertain evidence in other modalities such as language and language, and you can expand the stochastic CSP to limit these variables along with the current random variables that represent visual evidence and latent structures, so that a latent utterance describes a latent structure. You can then use the same highly probable estimation techniques to prove the most probable imaging is consistent with a structure that produces the most likely appearance.

referenceMentions.context: For example, Freyd et al. (1988) showed that physical forces, such as gravity, and whether such forces are in equilibrium, due to support and attachment relations, influences visual perception of object location in adults.

Wynn (1998) showed that material properties of objects, such as whether they are countable or mass substances, along with abstract properties, such as the number of countable objects and the quantity of mass substances, and how they are transferred between containers, influences visual perception in young infants.

While earlier Siddharth et al. (2011) demonstrated successful automatic determination of log occupancy at occluded log positions, we could only do so given manual annotation of log-feature visibility.
We solve the chickenand-egg problem inherent in doing so with an iterative algorithm reminiscent of expectation maximization (EM) (Baum, 1972; Baum et al., 1970; Dempster et al., 1977).

We then apply the structure estimation procedure developed in Siddharth et al. (2011) to estimate the occupancy of each symbolic grid position.

While the structure estimation process presented by Siddharth et al. (2011) can determine the occupancy of a small number of grid positions when only a single set of occupancy values is consistent with the grammar and the image evidence, it is not clairvoyant; it cannot determine the structure of an assembly when a large part of that assembly is occluded and many different possible structures are consistent with the image evidence.
We can combine the techniques from section 4 with these techniques to yield an active-vision (Bajcsy, 1988) approach to producing a confident and correct structure estimate.

We performed combined visibility and structure estimation on 105 of the 160 images and compared the maximum-likelihood structure estimate to that produced by Siddharth et al. (2011) using manual annotation of visibility.

metadata.abstractText: We present a framework that allows an observer to determine occluded portions of a structure by finding the maximum-likelihood estimate of those occluded portions consistent with visible image evidence and a consistency model. Doing this requires determining which portions of the structure are occluded in the first place. Since each process relies on the other, we determine a solution to both problems in tandem. We extend our framework to determine confidence of one’s assessment of which portions of an observed structure are occluded, and the estimate of that occluded structure, by determining the sensitivity of one’s assessment to potential new observations. We further extend our framework to determine a robotic action whose execution would allow a new observation that would maximally increase one’s confidence.
